docs.snippet: Facebook signaled its ambitions to grow as a payment platform, with changes to how its users can buy goods and services without leaving its site. It is also a clear signal to Wall Street that the company is pushing to make more money....
docs.abstract: Facebook signaled its ambitions to grow as a payment platform, with changes to how its users can buy goods and services without leaving its site. It is also a clear signal to Wall Street that the company is pushing to make more money.

headline.main: Facebook Shifts Its Approach to Payments
headline.print_headline: On Facebook, A Way to Use Real Money

docs.snippet: Turnout was spectacularly low in the digital republic of Facebook. The company asked user of the social network to vote on privacy polices. Only 0.04 percent of its members bothered, most opposing the new policies. The company announced that it wo...
docs.abstract: Turnout was spectacularly low in the digital republic of Facebook. The company asked user of the social network to vote on privacy polices. Only 0.04 percent of its members bothered, most opposing the new policies. The company announced that it would go ahead and adopt the proposals.

headline.main: Facebook Holds a Vote and Turnout Is Low

docs.snippet: Over the last two days, there has been a great deal of mud-slinging and hand-wringing about the significance of what Mark Zuckerberg, 27, the chief of executive of Facebook, wore when he went courting would-be investors in New York. Why the fascin...
docs.abstract: Over the last two days, there has been a great deal of mud-slinging and hand-wringing about the significance of what Mark Zuckerberg, 27, the chief of executive of Facebook, wore when he went courting would-be investors in New York. Why the fascination and why did some take offense?

headline.main: Why Is Everyone Focused on Zuckerberg's Hoodie?

docs.snippet: Although more than half of Facebook's 845 million members visit the site via a mobile device, the company has not yet found a way to make real money from that use....
docs.lead_paragraph: Amid the jaw-dropping financial figures that Facebook revealed last week when it filed for a public offering was an interesting admission. Although more than half of its 845 million members log in to Facebook on a mobile device, the company has not yet found a way to make real money from that use, reports Jenna Wortham of The New York Times.
docs.abstract: Although more than half of Facebook's 845 million members visit the site via a mobile device, the company has not yet found a way to make real money from that use.

docs.snippet: A new chief executive at Sony; Donald Trump will endorse Newt Gingrich; and how NBC used the Republican debate to boost Brian Williams's ratings....
docs.lead_paragraph: The Facebook initial public offering - with its goal of raising $5 billion, and a valuation of the company at $75 billion to $100 billion, offered a trove of stories for journalists to dig into.
docs.abstract: A new chief executive at Sony; Donald Trump will endorse Newt Gingrich; and how NBC used the Republican debate to boost Brian Williams's ratings.

headline.main: The Breakfast Meeting: A Look at Facebook's Books and Its 'Hacker' Way

docs.snippet: If Facebook's initial valuation pushes $100 billion, it would be far bigger than many established American companies, including Amazon, Caterpillar, Kraft Foods, Goldman Sachs and Ford Motor....
docs.lead_paragraph: With a huge initial public offering on the runway, Facebook has shown that it pays to have friends. New investors will now have to decide what they are willing to pay to be friends.
docs.abstract: If Facebook's initial valuation pushes $100 billion, it would be far bigger than many established American companies, including Amazon, Caterpillar, Kraft Foods, Goldman Sachs and Ford Motor.

headline.main: Investors Get the Chance to Assess Facebook's Potential

byline.original: By PETER EAVIS and EVELYN M. RUSLI

docs.snippet: Salman Rushdie cancels, citing assassination threat....
docs.lead_paragraph: The Jaipur Literature Festival got off to a macabre start on Friday with organizers announcing that the Indian-born author Salman Rushdie would not attend the event because of a new assassination threat against him. Instead, Mr. Rushdie said he would address the event via a video link.
docs.abstract: Salman Rushdie cancels, citing assassination threat.

headline.main: A Macabre Start to the Sprawling Jaipur Lit Fest
